text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 8.19.9, Non-TEFRA Procedures.
All Appeals employees working with non-TEFRA pass-through entity returns or
Table of
Form
-- Closing Package Mailed to Campus (case linked on PCS and Appeals does not all of the investors—Campus to mail agreements) Form
-- Closing Package Mailed to Examiner (case not inked on PCS and Appeals does not have all of the investors—Examiner to mail agreements)
) IRM

is intended to give appeals employees, including appeals officers, tax computation specialists, and Account and Processing Support (APS) specific guidance in working non-TEFRA pass-through entity cases, especially non-TEFRA key cases. Since non-TEFRA provisions require different technical and procedural treatment from those used for TEFRA cases, appeals employees should be familiar with the entire contents of this Handbook.

IRM 8.19.9 is intended to give appeals employees, including appeals officers, tax computation specialists, and Account and Processing Support (APS) specific guidance in working non-TEFRA pass-through entity cases, especially non-TEFRA key cases. Since non-TEFRA provisions require different technical and procedural treatment from those used for TEFRA cases, appeals employees should be familiar with the entire contents of this Handbook.

tax computation specialists, and Account and Processing Support (APS) specific guidance in working non-TEFRA pass-through entity cases, non-TEFRA key cases. Since non-TEFRA provisions require different and procedural treatment from those used for TEFRA cases, appeals employees should be familiar with the entire contents of this Handbook. Caution: Position titles and delegated authorities referenced in IRM
to reflect the results of the IRS reorganization. Users are cautioned to seek guidance from the Appeals Technical Specialist(s) for TEFRA if questions of authority arise. (
) The Appeals Office will have jurisdiction of the non-TEFRA key case. As a general rule, the non-TEFRA key case and one protesting investor case will sent to Appeals. (
) The non-TEFRA key case is any pass-through entity for which adjustments proposed and which is not subject to the TEFRA provisions. (

) All guidance in this section concerning the Campus TEFRA Functions is for cases controlled on the Partnership Control System (PCS). The CTFs only work with key cases and investors controlled on the PCS. (

) Account and Processing Support will card the non- TEFRA key case in on ACDS as a separate work unit, not as a reference return. This will allow to be charged to the case by the appeals officer. Use Type Code “I” instead “REF”. (
) If the non-TEFRA key case is an S Corporation (Form
-S), the feature code “FEATRCD” should be SB. (
) Unless the non-TEFRA key case is a taxable S Corporation, other workunit information should be as follows: a. STATDATE: Enter the actual statute date. b. CODE (statute code): Enter “RFRTN”. c. Prop
ax: No dollars should be entered. (
) If the non-TEFRA key case is a taxable S Corporation, other workunit tion should be as follows: a. STATDATE: Enter the actual statute date. b. CODE (statute code): No entry. c. Prop
ax: Enter the deficiency from the revenue agent report. (
) In the NOTES section “Non-TEFRA Key Case” may be entered and to: NNNNNNNNNN”. (NNNNNNNNNN = investor case work unit number(s)). Other identifying information may be included as space permits. (

) If a notice of deficiency is later issued on an investor case that is related to non-TEFRA key case and the unagreed issues include those raised for the non-TEFRA key case, the non-TEFRA key case should be moved to Part

the appeals officer’s timesheet if there is a petition filed to the Tax Court. docket number of the investor case should be entered on the non-TEFRA case in ACDS. The non-TEFRA key case should not be closed from either ACDS or AIMS, and instead should be sent to Counsel for answer along the investor case.
The non-TEFRA key case is any pass-through entity for which adjustments proposed and which is not subject to the TEFRA provisions.
8.19 Appeals Pass-Through Entity
) For more information, see IRM

) A non-TEFRA pass-through entity is any pass-through entity that does not under the TEFRA provisions. They are usually the types of entities below: Entity a. A partnership, LLC (limited liability company), or REMIC (real estate mortgage investment conduit) which meets the small partnership to TEFRA partnership rules and has not elected to be included under TEFRA rules as provided in IRC section
)(B); Note: An LLC, which has more than one member and has not elected to be fied as a corporation under Treas. Reg. section
(effective January
) is required to file Form

; an LLC that has only one member and has not elected to be classified as a corporation will be as a disregarded entity for federal income tax purposes. b. An S corporation whose tax period begins before January
, meets the small partnership exception to TEFRA S corporation rules has not elected to be included under TEFRA rules as provided in IRC section
)(B). c. An S corporation whose tax period begins after December
Small Business Job Protection Act of

made S corporations and shareholders subject to non-TEFRA procedures. S corporations cannot make an election to be subject to TEFRA after this date. d. A fiduciary or trust; a business entity which is not a trust or corporation that may be treated as a partnership or corporation (if as a corporation, S corporation election may be made); a joint venture; or similar type such as a REMIC. (

) A non-TEFRA pass-through entity: a. In general, has no tax liability for itself, but passes the tax to its partners, shareholders, beneficiaries, or investors. S corporations and Electing Large Partnerships occasionally pay tax at the entity level. b. Might not file a tax return and may not be required to file a return (i.e., a Schedule C or F syndication or promotion reported directly on each tor’s Form

). c. Has no unified proceeding as in TEFRA. There is also no Notice of Beginning of Administrative Proceeding (NBAP), Final Partnership istrative Adjustment (FPAA) or Final S Corporation Administrative Adjustment (FSAA) issued. However, a Notice of Beginning of Audit ( Letter
), Notice of Beginning of S Corporation Audit ( Letter
), or Notice of Beginning of Trust Audit ( Letter
) may be There are also similar letters that Compliance field offices use to keep taxpayers informed and similar procedures for linking investor cases on PCS. (
) An investor in a non-TEFRA entity may be examined for both pass-through and non pass-through issues. (

) Unlike TEFRA examinations, the issues cannot be split. If a statutory notice deficiency is later issued, it must contain ALL adjustments, both and non pass-through. Generally, unagreed, non-docketed cases sent to
A non-TEFRA pass-through entity is any pass-through entity that does not fall under the TEFRA provisions. They are usually the types of entities described
b. An S corporation whose tax period begins before January
, which meets the small partnership exception to TEFRA S corporation rules and has not elected to be included under TEFRA rules as provided in IRC section
)(B). c. An S corporation whose tax period begins after December
The Small Business Job Protection Act of

made S corporations and their shareholders subject to non-TEFRA procedures. S corporations cannot make an election to be subject to TEFRA after this date. d. A fiduciary or trust; a business entity which is not a trust or corporation that may be treated as a partnership or corporation (if as a corporation, S corporation election may be made); a joint venture; or similar type entity such as a REMIC.

a. In general, has no tax liability for itself, but passes the tax consequences to its partners, shareholders, beneficiaries, or investors. S corporations and Electing Large Partnerships occasionally pay tax at the entity level. b. Might not file a tax return and may not be required to file a return (i.e., a Schedule C or F syndication or promotion reported directly on each inves- tor’s Form

). c. Has no unified proceeding as in TEFRA. There is also no Notice of Beginning of Administrative Proceeding (NBAP), Final Partnership Admin- istrative Adjustment (FPAA) or Final S Corporation Administrative Adjustment (FSAA) issued. However, a Notice of Beginning of Partnership Audit ( Letter
), Notice of Beginning of S Corporation Audit ( Letter
), or Notice of Beginning of Trust Audit ( Letter
) may be issued. There are also similar letters that Compliance field offices use to keep taxpayers informed and similar procedures for linking investor cases on PCS.
) An investor in a non-TEFRA entity may be examined for both pass-through and non pass-through issues. (

) Unlike TEFRA examinations, the issues cannot be split. If a statutory notice of deficiency is later issued, it must contain ALL adjustments, both pass-through and non pass-through. Generally, unagreed, non-docketed cases sent to Appeals must include all non-pass-through and all non-TEFRA pass-through
page issues. Exceptions include issues referred under the Early Referral Program outlined in Rev. Proc.
, CB

) If an investor has more than one unresolved non-TEFRA pass-through issue, and all are not included in the examiner’s report (RAR), the appeals officer should consider returning the case to the Compliance office as a premature referral under IRM
) When a non-TEFRA key case is assigned, the appeals officer should follow procedures stated below in addition to normal procedures. (
) First review the case file to ensure that all necessary documents are included in the key case file and that the ACDS Case Summary Card is accurate. (
) Use IRM
to ensure that the partnership is not subject to the unified proceedings of TEFRA and IRM
to ensure that the S corporation is not subject to the unified proceedings of TEFRA. Pay particular attention to small partnership and small S corporation exceptions (IRM
and IRM
, respectively). An error in the determination of the of the small partnership or small S corporation exceptions may result in deficiencies. For partnership tax years ending after August
, the may rely on the information on the partnership tax return (if such reliance is reasonable) to determine whether the unified proceedings apply ( IRC section
(g)). If the determination is arguably not reasonable (e.g. an election exists), consult associate area counsel. All S corporations are non-TEFRA for tax years beginning after December

Use IRM 8.19.1.6.3 to ensure that the partnership is not subject to the unified proceedings of TEFRA and IRM 8.19.1.6.4 to ensure that the S corporation is not subject to the unified proceedings of TEFRA. Pay particular attention to small partnership and small S corporation exceptions (IRM 8.19.1.6.3.1 and IRM 8.19.1.6.4.1, respectively). 8.19 Appeals Pass-Through Entity
Appeals Pass-Through Entity (
) Forms
-S (partnerships),
-X (S corporations), and
-W (estates trusts) list each investor’s name and TIN, and are used to show each inves-
-X, and tor’s pro rata share of the corrected items. . (
) The appeals officer should verify that the shares of each item total
% of that item. The corrected items must also reconcile with the corrected shown on the examiner’s Form
-A. If these amounts do not reconcile, appeals officer should contact the examiner for clarification. (
) A written protest may be filed by any investor. Generally, only one investor will be sent to Appeals. (
) The statute of limitations for non-TEFRA pass-through entities, including TEFRA key cases, is controlled at the investor level. See IRC section
; of Limitations for Bufferd v. Commissioner,
U.S.

). Accordingly, any extension the statute of limitations for adjustments proposed to the pass-through Entity returns must be protected by securing a statute extension from each in the pass-through entity. (This is in contrast to TEFRA entities where the statute of limitations for each investor is extended by the tax matters person).
The statute of limitations for non-TEFRA pass-through entities, including non- TEFRA key cases, is controlled at the investor level. See IRC section
; Bufferd v. Commissioner,
U.S.

). Accordingly, any extension of the statute of limitations for adjustments proposed to the pass-through entity’s returns must be protected by securing a statute extension from each investor in the pass-through entity. (This is in contrast to TEFRA entities where the statute of limitations for each investor is extended by the tax matters partner/ person).
Note: As noted in IRM 8.19.9.4.1.1, Appeals is only responsible for statutes on investors that are received with a key case.

a. The statute extension at the investor level includes any issues unrelated to the investor’s share of adjustments for the non-TEFRA pass-through entity. b. The non-TEFRA pass-through entity’s statute on the AIMS database is updated to GG (i.e.
-GG-
) changing only the day. On ACDS, the actual statute date is entered, and “RFRTN” is entered for the statute code. See IRM
An exception is for S corporations, wherein an extension of the statute of limi- tations under IRC section
is needed where corporate level taxes under IRC sections
or
are raised, or where the S corporation is being
Example: A case where it was determined that no S corporation election was made. An extension of the statute would be needed as the corporation is now treated as a C corporation.
Example: A case where the S corporation is determined to owe built-in gains tax under IRC section 1374. An extension of the statute would be needed as the corporation owes taxes.
the corporation owes taxes. (

) The Service must notify the taxpayer (or authorized representative executing a consent) on each occasion when the taxpayer is requested to extend the statute by consent as to the following rights as required by IRC
)(B): a. The right to refuse to extend the limitations period. b. The right to request the extension to be limited to particular issues held open for further examination or appeal.
Procedures
of a restrictive paragraph is approved, refer to IRM
for in preparing the restrictive paragraph consent. c. The right to request the limitations period. d. Separate notification must be made to each spouse on joint returns (

) The Partnership Control System (PCS) is a database designed to control monitor pass-through entities and linked investor returns. It does not replace AIMS inventory control, but it provides the additional information needed to control investor and pass-through returns. It interfaces with AIMS to returns, access information, and provide mass updates to AIMS. (

) PCS allows an unlimited number of investors to be linked to each key case tier and allows an investor to be linked to an unlimited number of entities. The linkage charges the returns to the appropriate area office or and places a pass-through entity Partnership Investor Control File (PICF)
for the key case on the AIMS database. It also places an investor PICF Code

on the AIMS database so that any other part of the Service can see that an entity related to the investor return is under examination. This premature closure of an investor return until all key case issues are should also prevent improperly restricted statute extensions. (
) The PCS is described in detail in the text of IRM
, Partnership Control System (PCS) Handbook and IRM
, Pass-Through Entity Handbook. also IRM
) AIMS freeze code “H” is input on the non-TEFRA key case record to premature closing of the key case before the results of the examination are associated with all of the investors. (

) Non-TEFRA entities may or may not have been linked on PCS by the examiner. The numbers of investors and/or their geographic locations are and factors that are considered. If the case was linked on PCS, there will be a PICF code
on the AMDISA. (

) When the non-TEFRA key case is linked on PCS, the investor returns for SBSE cases are sent to the key case CTF, which is responsible for the statute on the investor cases. For investor cases already charged out to either SBSE or LB&I, the examiner with control of the investor case has the statute responsibility. The CTF will also secure agreements, assess tax and send notices of deficiency when necessary. The CTF for SBSE cases is Brookhaven, while the CTF for LB&I cases is Ogden. (

) For non-TEFRA entities that are linked on PCS, in order to determine which CTF is the key case CTF, follow these steps: a. Order IDRS Command Code TSINQP on each year of the key case. b. Look in the “CTF” field for either “OSC” (Ogden) or “BSC” c. If the TSINQP shows Ogden, then Ogden is the key case Campus. d. If the TSINQP shows Brookhaven, then order IDRS Command Code TXMODC on the non-TEFRA key case; if there is no data, then Ogden the key case Campus; if there is data, look in the “Control Base and History Information” section; if the “Assign To” column has numbers that begin with
, then Brookhaven is the key case Campus; if there are numbers in the “Assign To” column, then Ogden is the key case Internal Revenue Manual
For non-TEFRA entities that are linked on PCS, in order to determine CTF is the key case CTF, follow these steps:

Order IDRS Command Code TSINQP on each year of the key case. Look in the “CTF” field for either “OSC” (Ogden) or “BSC” (Brookhaven). If the TSINQP shows Ogden, then Ogden is the key case Campus. If the TSINQP shows Brookhaven, then order IDRS Command Code TXMODC on the non-TEFRA key case; if there is no data, then Ogden is the key case Campus; if there is data, look in the “Control Base and History Information” section; if the “Assign To” column has numbers that begin with
, then Brookhaven is the key case Campus; if there are numbers in the “Assign To” column, then Ogden is the key case Campus.
8.19 Appeals Pass-Through Entity Handbook
Appeals Pass-Through Entity (
) The PCS system places a PICF Code
on the AIMS record for the investor. The code alerts personnel to the existence of an ongoing examination of the key case return and prevents its premature closure. (

) If the non-TEFRA key case is not linked on PCS, the key case examiner is sponsible for statute control for all of the investor returns. The CTF has no responsibility for any statute protection for any investor unless that investor is in the CTF because of another non-TEFRA linkage. (

) As a general rule, the key case and one protesting investor case will be sent to Appeals. Exceptions are: a. If protesting investors have different representatives, one case from representative is sent to Appeals. b. If an investor has no representative and files a protest, the investor case is sent to Appeals. c. If there are unagreed non-pass-through issues, the investor case is sent Appeals. (
) Most of the other investor returns are held in suspense (at the key case even if the investor does not respond to the

-day letter. However, the CTF will transfer the following investor returns to an examination group: a. Coordinated Industry Case (CIC) corporations; b. Joint Committee cases; and c. Other corporate specialty cases. Note: For Compliance’s purposes, other corporate specialty cases are Forms with letters after the
(other than A, S, or X).. (

) If the key case is not linked on PCS, Appeals will only accept protesting investor cases if both of the following conditions are met: a. The non-TEFRA key case has five or fewer investors, and b. None of the investors is a pass-through entity. Note: If a case that is not linked on PCS fails to meet the above criteria, the key case examiner must either link the case before it is sent to Appeals or responsibility for the investor returns. (
) Appeals is responsible for statute protection on any investor returns that it receives with the non-TEFRA key case. (

) Generally, the key case pass-through entity and one investor will be sent to Appeals, therefore there will only be a conference for that investor. However, Procedures additional investors are sent to Appeals with the key case, each is entitled to an Appeals conference. (

) If there is only one investor, the conference for any issues raised in the key case will be offered in the Appeals Office servicing the area where the pass- through entity has its principal place of business. However, the conference may be held at a location closer to the investor’s residence or place of business, and the books and records are available there. Refer to IRM
, Transfers for the Convenience of Taxpayers. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
A
even if the investor does not respond to the

-day letter. However, the will transfer the following investor returns to an examination group: a. Coordinated Industry Case (CIC) corporations; b. Joint Committee cases; and c. Other corporate specialty cases. Note: For Compliance’s purposes, other corporate specialty cases are Forms with letters after the
(other than A, S, or X).. (

) If the key case is not linked on PCS, Appeals will only accept protesting investor cases if both of the following conditions are met: a. The non-TEFRA key case has five or fewer investors, and b. None of the investors is a pass-through entity. Note: If a case that is not linked on PCS fails to meet the above criteria, the key case examiner must either link the case before it is sent to Appeals or responsibility for the investor returns. (
) Appeals is responsible for statute protection on any investor returns that it receives with the non-TEFRA key case. (

) Generally, the key case pass-through entity and one investor will be sent to Appeals, therefore there will only be a conference for that investor. additional investors are sent to Appeals with the key case, each is entitled an Appeals conference. (

) If there is only one investor, the conference for any issues raised in the key case will be offered in the Appeals Office servicing the area where the pass- through entity has its principal place of business. However, the conference may be held at a location closer to the investor’s residence or place of business, and the books and records are available there. Refer to IRM
, Transfers for the Convenience of Taxpayers.
Note: For Compliance’s purposes, other corporate specialty cases are Forms 1120 with letters after the 1120 (other than A, S, or X)..
If the key case is not linked on PCS, Appeals will only accept protesting investor cases if both of the following conditions are met:
page 7

) In general, if there is more than one investor, the conference for any issues raised in the key case will be offered in the Appeals Office servicing the area where the pass-through entity has its principal place of business. However, if there is agreement among all of the investors whose cases are in Appeals, conference may be held at a location closer to a selected investor’s or place of business, and the books and records are available there. Note: Any other issues raised with respect to the investors can generally not be handled at the conference on the key case issues unless the investors the same representative. (

) If the conference requires space to accommodate a large group of the appeals officer should inquire if adequate government facilities are available. However, if it is necessary to rent conference space, the investors should make the arrangements and be responsible for the cost. (
) The appeals officer should be mindful of procedural problems that certain settlement offers may cause for the CTFs in processing the case. (

) Avoid settlements based upon a net cash investment unless the examining agent has already substantiated the amount of each investor’s cash invest- Net ment. The CTFs will not have the means to verify cash investments for investors in suspense. (

) If the correct allocation of the interest in the key case is an issue being ered, do not settle an investor case unless all investors (including those that may be in suspense at a CTF or which were retained by the examiner) agree to the allocation by executing Form
) If either the key case CTF or the examiner is holding investors in suspense, and will be mailing the Forms
(AD) to those investors, include instructions on Form

(as part of the closing package) to alert the key case CTF or examiner to return the agreement forms to the appeals officer without executing them. The appeals officer should include envelopes to ensure that the CTF or examiner returns the agreements to the appeals officer. (

) Notify the appeals officer or manager assigned to execute agreements at the CTF (or the examiner) that any agreements received should be returned to appeals officer that is assigned the non-TEFRA key case in order to be executed. (
) Refer to IRM
and IRM
for more information on issues. (
) See IRM
for further guidance on securing agreements from the investors and preparing and mailing the closing package. (

) If penalties are asserted on investors as a result of adjustments to the key case return, the appeals officer will review the RAR and determine a recom- mended settlement position on the penalties based upon the activities at the key case level. This will include the overvaluation of assets. (
) The appeals officer will prepare an abbreviated appeals case memo (ACM) the recommended settlement position on the penalties. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
8.19.9.6 (07-01-2006) Settlement Practice
8.19.9.6.1 (07-01-2006) Settlements for Net Cash Investment
See IRM 8.19.9.9 for further guidance on securing agreements from the other investors and preparing and mailing the closing package.
The appeals officer will prepare an abbreviated appeals case memo (ACM) the recommended settlement position on the penalties.
Appeals Pass-Through Entity (

) The recommended settlement position will be based upon the activities at key case level only. Any additional facts, which are based on the activities the investor level, will be considered in evaluating the investor’s individual case. If no additional facts are presented at the investor level, follow the ment position recommended at the key case entity level. (

) Account and Processing Support will mail a copy of the abbreviated penalty ACM to the key case CTF (or the examiner) as part of the closing package, and will retain a copy in the office file. See IRM
for the that should be included in a closing package. (
) Penalties on non-TEFRA cases are not subject to the consistent settlement rules of TEFRA provided in IRC section
). But, the Service strives consistent settlements generally. (

) At the conclusion of the settlement negotiations, the appeals officer will prepare an ACM for the non-TEFRA key case reflecting the revised adjust- Preparation at ments, and any settlements recommended. of Negotiations (
) The appeals officer will follow the usual format in preparing an ACM for non- TEFRA key cases. Case Memo (
) Include an evaluation of each penalty in an abbreviated ACM. The proposal settlement of the penalties will become the key case position for all (

) Account and Processing Support will mail a copy of the ACM (and the ACM if applicable) to the key case CTF (or the examiner) as part of the package, and will retain copies in the office file. See IRM
for the documents that should be included in a closing package. (
) The Appeals tax computation specialist will prepare the following forms for non-TEFRA key case, provided that there were changes made to the forms already in the case file: a. Form
-S for partnerships, Form
-X for S corporations, and Form
-W for estates and trusts b. Form

) The Appeals tax computation specialist will prepare an audit statement for each investor case that is in Appeals. (

(AD) (non-docketed investors) or decision documents (docketed investors) should be secured from the investor(s) in Appeals. The CTF will mail Form

for more guidance on allocation issues. (

) Closing agreements from partners in a partnership or shareholders in an S poration should be avoided if possible. If the key case becomes a TEFRA entity in a subsequent tax year, on the date a closing agreement is the one-year minimum assessment period under IRC

(f) is triggered for subsequent years covered in the closing agreement, unless the agreement constitutes a partial agreement. Also, a closing agreement may have been unintended result of making adjustments that could foreclose further adjust- ments in a separate TEFRA proceeding for the same tax year. (

) Closing agreements relating to non-TEFRA entities should be entered into with the individual investors and not the entity. This is because a closing agreement with the entity will not be binding on the investors. Note: A closing agreement with a non-TEFRA entity may be sought to encourage the entity to file subsequent year returns in a specified manner. The agreement will not bind the individual investors. Separate closing agree- ments should be sought from each investor. Internal Revenue Manual

The Appeals tax computation specialist will prepare an audit statement for any investor case that is in Appeals if the investor case has other issues.

Closing agreements from partners in a partnership or shareholders in an S poration should be avoided if possible. If the key case becomes a TEFRA entity in a subsequent tax year, on the date a closing agreement is executed, the one-year minimum assessment period under IRC

(f) is triggered for subsequent years covered in the closing agreement, unless the agreement constitutes a partial agreement. Also, a closing agreement may have been the unintended result of making adjustments that could foreclose further adjust- ments in a separate TEFRA proceeding for the same tax year.

A PICF code

indicates at least one open non-TEFRA key linkage and TEFRA key case linkages. Command code TSUMYI should then be secured for each tax year of the investor to identify any other open non- TEFRA linkages apart from the non-TEFRA key case that is being considered by Appeals. See IRM

Appeals Pass-Through Entity c. A PICF code

indicates no open key case linkages and at least one closed TEFRA key case linkage. This would mean that the investor in non-TEFRA key case being considered by Appeals was not linked to non-TEFRA key case on PCS. The audit statement should begin with taxable income as corrected based on any assessments from the TEFRA linkages. See IRM
for additional procedures to follow. d. A PICF code

indicates no open key case linkages and at least one closed non-TEFRA key case linkage but no closed TEFRA key case linkages. This would mean that the investor in the non-TEFRA key case being considered by Appeals was not linked to the non-TEFRA key on PCS. The audit statement should begin with taxable income as corrected based on any assessments from the closed non-TEFRA linkages. e. A PICF code

indicates no open key case linkages. This would also mean that the investor in the non-TEFRA key case being considered by Appeals was not linked to the non-TEFRA key case on PCS. The audit statement should begin with taxable income from the return or from any prior assessments (if any). (

Any special instructions (such as what type of agreement should be secured from each investor in suspense, or to return all agreement to Appeals because there is an allocation issue or they require Appeals approval and signature).

a. Order IDRS Command Code TSINQP on each year of the key case. b. Look in the “CTF” field for either “OSC” (Ogden) or “BSC” (Brookhaven). c. If the TSINQP shows Ogden, then Ogden is the key case Campus. d. If the TSINQP shows Brookhaven, then order IDRS Command Code TXMODC on the non-TEFRA key case; if there is no data, then Ogden is the key case Campus; if there is data, look in the “Control Base and History Information” section; if the “Assign To” column has numbers that begin with
, then Brookhaven is the key case Campus; if there are no numbers in the “Assign To” column, then Ogden is the key case Campus.

) If revised tax computations are needed based on the settlement, the officer is responsible for requesting the tax computation specialist to begin preparing the closing package and Form
Note: If at the time that the tax computation specialist prepares the closing package and the Form
, some of the documents have not yet been prepared by the appeals officer (for example, the ACM or Form
) or formation is not yet available, the appeals officer will complete the preparation of the closing package. (
) If revised tax computations are not needed based on the settlement, the appeals officer is responsible for preparing the closing package and Form
) The appeals officer, secretary, clerk, or Account and Processing Support determined locally) will make photocopies of the documents to be included the completed closing package. (
) In all situations, the appeals officer is responsible for: a. the accuracy and completeness of the Form
, b. reviewing the completed closing package, and c. submitting it to Appeals Processing Services. (
) Account and Processing Support is responsible for: a. ensuring all documents listed on the Form
are attached, b. sending the completed package to the CTF and/or examiner by mail, and c. monitoring the return of the acknowledged Form
APS will maintain suspense copies of Forms
with instructions to mail room for the acknowledgement copy to be returned.
Place suspense copies of Forms
in a review file and check daily verify the document has been received.
The acknowledgement copies of all Forms
must be documented the date received.
If after ten (
) business days the receipt has not been acknowledged, originator must follow-up to resolve the missing acknowledgement and document the actions taken.
The documentation must either be recorded on or attached to the tor’s copy of the Forms
When items are determined to be lost in transit, APS should notify the appeals officer who will determine the appropriate procedures to (
